content:
The leader of the wrap-span">Catholic Church takes wrap-span">decisive action after months of wrap-span">flip-wrap-span">flops

wrap-span">ARCHBISHOP Georg Gänswein, secretary to the last wrap-span">Pope, once compared the impact of the sexual-abuse wrap-span">scandals in the wrap-span">Catholic Church to that of 9/11 on the wrap-span">secular world. In the most recent development a study commissioned by the German church, which leaked, found that more than 1,500 clergymen there had for decades been abusing wrap-span">minors. On September 12th wrap-span">Pope wrap-span">Francis responded at last, calling the leaders of every wrap-span">Catholic wrap-span">hierarchy in the world to a conference in Rome to discuss the continuing—indeed, deepening—crisis. The heads of all the world’s wrap-span">Catholic bishops’ conferences—more than a hundred wrap-span">prelates—will be expected to attend, from February 21st to 24th.

The announcement follows a terrible summer for the church. In July the wrap-span">pope accepted the wrap-span">resignation of wrap-span">Cardinal wrap-span">Theodore McCarrick, the retired wrap-span">Archbishop of Washington, who is accused of taking advantage of his position over many years to make sexual advances to wrap-span">seminarians. The following month a grand wrap-span">jury in wrap-span">Pennsylvania published an investigation wrap-span">stretching back seven decades that wrap-span">chronicled in often wrap-span">horrific detail the abuses of more than 300 wrap-span">priests in the state which, it said, their wrap-span">superiors had ignored and covered up. In August, the former wrap-span">papal wrap-span">nuncio, or wrap-span">ambassador, in America, wrap-span">Archbishop Carlo Maria Viganò, wrap-span">alleged that wrap-span">Francis himself had covered up for former wrap-span">Cardinal McCarrick. He called on the wrap-span">pope to resign. wrap-span">Francis wrap-span">initially refused to comment and appeared to think no action was required.

By calling the wrap-span">convention of bishops, the wrap-span">pope has wrap-span">tacitly accepted that that is not going to work. His U-turn is damaging in itself. But potentially far more dangerous is wrap-span">Archbishop Viganò’s wrap-span">allegation. It highlights wrap-span">Francis’s weakest point—his repeated mishandling of wrap-span">clerical sex-abuse wrap-span">allegations. Earlier this year he wrap-span">vigorously defended a wrap-span">Chilean bishop accused of wrap-span">shielding wrap-span">predators, only to then accept he had made a mistake. Moreover, wrap-span">Archbishop Viganò’s wrap-span">intervention has allowed the wrap-span">pope’s wrap-span">theologically wrap-span">conservative critics to make common cause with those, including many who applaud wrap-span">Francis’s wrap-span">liberal reforms, who are wrap-span">dismayed by the wrap-span">pope’s tone-deafness when it comes to dealing with wrap-span">clerical sex abuse, and especially the failure of bishops to protect victims.

The abuses that have so far been wrap-span">uncovered have mostly been in the rich world, perhaps because respect for the institution has kept them under wraps elsewhere. But that has been enough to force action. The American church holds unrivalled influence and financial wrap-span">sway over the Vatican, and many there wrap-span">urgently want root-and-branch reform. Some wrap-span">Catholics wrap-span">suspect wrap-span">Archbishop Viganò of acting out of wrap-span">spite, perhaps because wrap-span">Francis did not make him a wrap-span">cardinal. But in this affair it is the message, not the wrap-span">messenger, that counts, and wrap-span">Francis has so far failed to wrap-span">discredit it. If the conference produces wrap-span">radical action to deal with the wrap-span">misdeeds, not just of wrap-span">priests but of the wrap-span">prelates who covered up for them, then the wrap-span">pope can perhaps turn the tide. But the danger is that it will be seen as a yet another way to keep the lid on a crisis that continues to wrap-span">boil, and wrap-span">scald.

无论他在美国或利比里亚，都应该对他进行刑事侦查，追究这些可怕的罪行。
The idea that this is civilization\'s final century is horrific not only because of the loss and suffering, but because of the guilt of what we might have done to prevent it.
我个人觉得这是人类文明的末世纪，是极其可怕的，不仅是因为损失和痛苦，更是因为我们可以去拯救而不去做的一种罪过。

, the project will mainly focus on Java, where most of the human deaths have occurred.

ex: v. 包；用…包裹（或包扎、覆盖等）；用…缠绕（或围紧）；（使文字）换行
n. 围巾；包裹（或包装）材料；停机
网络 外套；卷；披肩
eg2: He spent the evening wrapping up the Christmas presents.
他花了一个晚上的时间把圣诞礼物都包了起来。
individually wrapped chocolates
单块包装的巧克力
Wrap the meat in foil before you cook it.
把肉用锡箔裹起来后再烹调。
I wrapped the baby (up) in a blanket.
我用毯子把婴儿裹了起来。
I wrapped a blanket around the baby.
我用毯子把婴儿裹了起来。
A scarf was wrapped around his neck.
他的脖子上围着一条围巾。
His arms were wrapped around her waist.
他的双臂紧紧环抱她的腰。
How can I wrap the text around?
我怎么才能使文本换行呢？
The text wraps around if it is too long to fit the screen.
如果文本太长，在显示屏放不下的话，会自动换行。
We stock a wide range of cards and gift wrap .
我们备有各种各样的贺卡和礼品包装材料。
Cut! That's a wrap.
停！就拍摄到这儿。
Next year's collection is still being kept under wraps.
明年的时装系列仍在保密之中。

Title: Pope Francis summons his bishops to discuss sexual abuse
